citation.article-title: Pseudomonas cedrina subsp. fulgida subsp. nov., a fluorescent bacterium isolated from the phyllosphere of grasses; emended description of Pseudomonas cedrina and description of Pseudomonas cedrina subsp. cedrina subsp. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Pseudomonas cedrina subsp. fulgida subsp. nov.
Pseudomonas cedrina subsp. fulgida (ful′gi.da. L. fem. adj. fulgida flashing, glittering, shining, pertaining to the bright fluorescence).
Cells are Gram-negative, non-spore-forming rods of about 0.8 μm in diameter and 2.5–4.2 μm in length that occur singly.
They are motile by one or two polar flagella.
The white–yellowish colonies on King B medium are smooth with regular margins and they produce a pigment that gives off a light yellow–green fluorescence when irradiated with UV-light.
Does not hydrolyse starch or casein.
Ice nucleation activity and formation of H2S from sodium thiosulphate are negative.
Growth can be observed at 4 °C, but none of the isolates are able to grow at 41 °C.
Further physiological features are presented in Table 1.
The type strain, P 515/12T (=DSM 14938T=LMG 21467T), was isolated from the phyllosphere of grasses in Paulinenaue (Germany).
